description.narrative: By improving the railway's infrastructure and rolling stock, the Project would have a substantial development impact. In particular, it would: (i) increase competition in the transport sector, reducing costs and leading to service improvements; (ii) shift traffic from road to rail (especially heavy bulk cargoes), slowing the deterioration of the road network and improving safety; (iii) increase regional integration in transportation, trade and economic development; (iv) by reducing transportation costs, facilitate economic growth particularly in Uganda and other landlocked countries in the region; and (v) by substituting trucks, reduce the emission of harmful greenhouse gases.

The Project would invest in Africa Railways Limited (ARL), a holding company established to hold a controlling stake in Rift Valley Railways (RVR). RVR is the operator of the Kenya-Uganda railway line which was privatized under two substantially identical 25-year concessions in 2006. IFCs Corporate Advisory Services acted as a financial advisor to the Government of Kenya for the 2006 privatization and, at that time, IFC made available an A Loan of $22 million and C Loan of $10 million (project #24766). Given the long distances involved (530 km from Mombasa to Nairobi and 803 km from there to Kampala), this should have a significant cost advantage over trucks. However, following decades of under-investment the network is in poor condition. The Project is part of a larger restructuring and investment program to put the railway back onto a sustainable footing with the goal of increasing cargo volumes from about 1.6 million tons currently to over 5.0 million tons by 2020.
